These [vaccines](/wiki/Vaccine) use a copy of a molecule called [messenger RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA) (mRNA) to carry instructions for proteins to produce an [immune response](/wiki/Immune_response). [[5]](#cite_note-5) [[1]](#cite_note-10K-1) The company's name and "modern". [[6]](#cite_note-moderna-about-6) [[7]](#cite_note-stat-story-7) [[8]](#cite_note-servick-8) is the [Moderna COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine), marketed as Spikevax. The company has 45 treatment and vaccine candidates, of which 38 have entered [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial). Candidates include [Zika virus vaccine](/wiki/Zika_virus_vaccine) funded by the [Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority](/wiki/Biomedical_Advanced_Research_and_Development_Authority), and three [cancer vaccines](/wiki/Cancer_vaccine). The company's [acute decompensated heart includes medicine](/wiki/Regenerative_medicine) treatment that factor Bancel](/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Bancel), CEO, was appointed as CEO in 2011. [[6]](#cite_note-moderna-about-6) [[10]](#cite_note-Ego-10) Between 2011 and 2017, Product development[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Moderna&action=edit§ion=2)] In 2013, the company formed a partnership with [AstraZeneca](/wiki/AstraZeneca) to develop treatments for cardiovascular, metabolic, and renal diseases, as well as cancer. In January 2014, the company entered an agreement with [Alexion Pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Alexion_Pharmaceuticals) to develop treatments against ten diseases. [[11]](#cite_note-11) On January 14, 2014, Moderna announced the creation of its first spinoff company, Onkaido Therapeutics, to focus "exclusively on developing mRNA-based [[13]](#cite_note-13) It launched its second spinoff, Valera, in January 2015, with a focus on "viral, bacterial and parasitic infectious diseases." [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15) Employees of Valera and Moderna would go on to develop an mRNA vaccine candidate against [Zika virus](/wiki/Zika_virus) infection. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Another spinoff, Elpidera, was announced in May 2015 to continue work on RNA therapies advancing Moderna's work with Alexion. [[17]](#cite_note-17) [[18]](#cite_note-18) In 2015, the company formed a partnership with [Merck & Co.](/wiki/Merck_%26_Co.) to develop treatments for cancer, and in 2016 the company formed a partnership with [Vertex Pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Vertex_Pharmaceuticals) to develop treatments for [cystic In January 2016, the [Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation](/wiki/Bill_%26_Melinda_Gates_Foundation) committed to provide at least $20 million in [grant](/wiki/Grant_(money)) funding to the company. [[1]](#cite_note-10K-1) In July 2018, the company opened a 200,000 square foot facility in [Norwood, Massachusetts](/wiki/Norwood,_Massachusetts) for manufacturing, preclinical and clinical work. [[6]](#cite_note-moderna-about-6) [[22]](#cite_note-22) In December 2018, Moderna became a [public company](/wiki/Public_company) via the largest [initial public offering](/wiki/Initial_public_offering) of a biotechnology company in history, raising $621 million by selling 27 million shares at $23 per share. [[23]](#cite_note-23) [[24]](#cite_note-24) The first mRNA vaccine developed by Moderna was for [influenza](/wiki/Influenza) in 2015, and its first [antibody](/wiki/Antibody) encoded by mRNA was in 2019. [[6]](#cite_note-moderna-about-6) In 2023, Moderna acquired OriCiro Genomics, a Japanese manufacturer of [genetic engineering](/wiki/Genetic_engineering) tools, in its first acquisition. [[25]](#cite_note-25) In early 2023, the company in collaboration with [Merck](/wiki/Merck_%26_Co.) won [breakthrough status](/wiki/Breakthrough_therapy) from the FDA for its [mRNA-4157/V940](/wiki/MRNA-4157/V940) drug candidate, a [cancer vaccine](/wiki/Cancer_vaccine). [[26]](#cite_note-natmed1-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) On 5 July 2023, the company announced that it entered an agreement with the Chinese government to develop mRNA drugs for exclusive use in the PRC despite political tensions between the two nations. The development of new products "would address the growing need by China to supply effective drugs to its aging population with higher rates of chronic diseases and health concerns stemming from an increasingly westernised diet", according to the statement. [[28]](#cite_note-28) COVID-19 vaccine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Moderna&action=edit§ion=3)] 2020 to 2021, Moderna received $955 million from [Operation Warp Speed](/wiki/Operation_Warp_Speed) to accelerate development of its COVID-19 vaccine, with $4.9 billion committed in total for producing 300 million vaccine doses. [[29]](#cite_note-29) [[30]](#cite_note-30) In March 2020, the [Food and [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial) for the [Moderna COVID19 vaccine](/wiki/Moderna_COVID%E2%80%9119_vaccine) candidate, and in December, the vaccine, mRNA-1273, was issued an [emergency use authorization](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorization) in the United States. [[31]](#cite_note-31) [[32]](#cite_note-32) In 2022, it gained FDA approval both [monovalent vaccine](/wiki/Vaccine#Valence), Spikevax, and Biopharma](/wiki/Arbutus_Biopharma) and Genevant Sciences filed a lawsuit against Moderna, accusing the company of seven counts of [patent infringement](/wiki/Patent_infringement). [[34]](#cite_note-34) In April 2022, Moderna announced plans to build a $180 million vaccine factory in [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal), forming a 10-year partnership with the [Government of Canada](/wiki/Government_of_Canada), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec), and [McGill University](/wiki/McGill_University) to produce 100 million Spikevax doses annually and expand vaccine research capabilities. [[35]](#cite_note-35) In August 2022, Moderna sued [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer) and [BioNTech](/wiki/BioNTech) in both Massachusetts and Germany, alleging that the [Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/Pfizer%E2%80%93BioNTech_COVID-19_vaccine) violates the patent on Moderna's [mRNA vaccine](/wiki/MRNA_vaccine) technology. [[36]](#cite_note-36) In February 2023, the company agreed to pay $400 million to the [National Institutes of Health](/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health), [Dartmouth College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College), and [Scripps Research](/wiki/Scripps_Research) to settle a dispute over the rights to a chemical technique that was used in the vaccine. [[37]](#cite_note-37) On March 10, 2023, U.S. District Judge [Mitchell Goldberg](/wiki/Mitchell_Goldberg) rejected a bid by Moderna to dismiss some of the patent infringement claims brought against the company by Arbutus Biopharma and Genevant Inc.
